desc: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 5A (STAT5A) is a transcription factor that is activated by cytokines and growth factors including interleukin 2,3, and 7 (IL2, IL3, IL7), Granulocyte Macrophage- colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF), erythropoietin, thrombopoietin, and growth hormones (PMID:15313458, 9630227, 7744007). It is phosphorylated by Janus kinase (JAK) kinases, resulting in dimerization and nuclear translocation (PMID:25527793). STAT5A regulates development and differentiation of tissues and cells including the mammary gland, hepatocytes, erythrocytes, platelets, and B-cells and T-Cells (PMID:15711548, 9009201, 11290598, 18347089, 24497979). STAT5A activation is involved in tumor progression, resistance, and transformation in various tissues including prostate cancer and breast cancer (PMID:23675504, 18508994). In leukemias and myeloproliferative neoplasms, STAT5A signaling may be activated through mutations in the JAK proteins or the FLT3 receptor (PMID:17356133, 17379095, 22234689). Copy number alternation have been identified in breast cancer samples (PMID: 25470049).

desc: STAT5A encodes a transcription factor involved in the JAK signaling cascade. Mutations of STAT5A are found in prostate and breast cancers and leukemias, among others.

gene.name: signal transducer and activator of transcription 5A
